context:
This is a gigantic movement of city construction, necessary for the residential settlement of this population, as well as for their work, supply, transportation, health, energy, water needs, etc. Even though the direction taken by urban growth has not satisfactorily met all these needs, the territory was occupied and the conditions for living in this space were built.

MARICATO, E. Brazil, cities: alternatives for the urban crisis. Petrópolis: Vozes, 2001.
question: What is the main reason for the gigantic movement of city construction mentioned in the text?
options: {'A': 'Work needs', 'B': 'Supply', 'C': 'Transportation', 'D': 'Health', 'E': 'Residential settlement'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about urban growth and city construction. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for the given information. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'E: Residential settlement' aligns with the main reason mentioned in the text.
steps_answer: The main reason for the gigantic movement of city construction mentioned in the text is for the residential settlement of the population, as stated in the passage.

context:
On July 1st, 2012, the city of Rio de Janeiro 
became the first in the world to receive the title of 
UNESCO World Heritage as a Cultural Landscape. 
The application, submitted by the National Institute of Historic 
and Artistic Heritage (Iphan), was approved 
during the 36th Session of the World Heritage Committee. 
The president of Iphan explained that 'the carioca landscape 
is the most explicit image of what we can call 
Brazilian civilization, with its originality, challenges, 
contradictions, and possibilities'. From now on, the 
places in the city valued with the UNESCO title will be 
the target of integrated actions aimed at preserving its 
cultural landscape.

Available at: www.cultura.gov.br. Accessed on: Mar 7, 2013 (adapted).
question: What was the date on which the city of Rio de Janeiro received the UNESCO title of World Heritage as a Cultural Landscape?
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the city of Rio de Janeiro receiving the UNESCO title. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct option is not marked.
steps_answer: The passage states that on July 1st, 2012, the city of Rio de Janeiro became the first in the world to receive the title of UNESCO World Heritage as a Cultural Landscape.

context:
TEXT I

Some time ago I realized that, since my early years, I had received many false opinions as true, and that what I later founded on such poorly secured principles could only be very doubtful and uncertain. It was necessary to seriously try, once in my life, to get rid of all the opinions to which I had previously given credit, and start all over again in order to establish a firm and unshakable knowledge.

DESCARTES, R. Meditations on First Philosophy. São Paulo: Abril Cultural, 1973 (adapted).

TEXT II

It is the radical nature of what is sought that demands the radicalization of the search process itself. If all space is occupied by doubt, any certainty that appears from there will have been in some way generated by doubt itself, and will certainly not be any of those that were previously swept away by that same doubt.
SILVA, F. L. Descartes: the metaphysics of modernity. São Paulo: Moderna, 2001 (adapted).
question: According to Text I, why did Descartes feel the need to get rid of all the opinions he had credited?
options: {'A': 'Because he realized that his opinions were true.', 'B': 'Because he founded his principles on solid grounds.', 'C': 'Because his opinions were doubtful and uncertain due to false information received.', 'D': 'Because he did not care about the veracity of his opinions.', 'E': 'Because he did not have enough knowledge to form opinions.'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'Because his opinions were doubtful and uncertain due to false information received.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided from Text I. It requires understanding of Descartes' motivation to get rid of his previous opinions. The bloom taxonomy level 'Understand' is appropriate as it requires comprehension of the text. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'C' accurately reflects Descartes' realization of the doubtful and uncertain nature of his opinions. Overall, a well-constructed and relevant multiple-choice question.
system_answer: {C: Because his opinions were doubtful and uncertain due to false information received.}
steps_answer: Descartes felt the need to get rid of all the opinions he had credited because he realized that since his early years, he had received many false opinions as true, which led to founding principles on poorly secured grounds, resulting in very doubtful and uncertain knowledge.

context:
From end to end, it's all beach-palm, very flat and 
very beautiful. Through the backlands, it seemed to us, seen from the sea, 
very large, because, stretching our eyes, we could not 
see anything but land with trees, which seemed very 
long to us. So far, we could not find out if there is gold, 
nor silver, nor anything made of metal or iron; nor did we see it. But the land itself has very good airs [...]. But the best fruit that can be taken from it seems to me 
that it will be to save these people.

Letter from Pero Vaz de Caminha. In: MARQUES, A.; BERUTTI, F.; FARIA, R. 
Modern history through texts. São Paulo: Contexto, 2001.
question: What is the main characteristic of the land described by Pero Vaz de Caminha?
options: {'A': 'Presence of gold and silver.', 'B': 'Long and wooded extension.', 'C': 'Unfavorable climate.', 'D': 'Dense population.', 'E': 'Lack of vegetation.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided from the letter by Pero Vaz de Caminha. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for the information given. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option aligns with the main characteristic described in the text.
steps_answer: Pero Vaz de Caminha describes the land as very large with trees that seemed very long to them, indicating a long and wooded extension.

context:
The sad song of the conquered: 
the last days of Tenochtitlán 

In the paths lie broken darts;
hair is scattered.
The houses are roofless,
The waters are red, the rivers, as if someone 
had dyed them,
In the shields was our protection,
but the shields do not hold back the desolation...

PINSKY, J. et al. History of America through texts. 
São Paulo: Contexto, 2007 (fragment).
question: What was the situation of the houses in Tenochtitlán in the last days described in the text?
options: {'A': 'Roofless', 'B': 'Painted blue', 'C': 'Completely destroyed', 'D': 'Reformed', 'E': 'Abandoned'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the last days of Tenochtitlán. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question provides enough information to arrive at an answer. However, the correctness score is 1 as the correct option is 'Roofless', which matches the description in the text.
steps_answer: The text describes the houses in Tenochtitlán in the last days as 'roofless', indicating that the roofs of the houses were missing or destroyed.

context:
The International Brigades 

 were units of 
 fighters formed by volunteers from 53 nationalities 
 willing to fight in defense of the Spanish Republic. 
 It is estimated that about 60,000 citizens from various 
 parts of the world - including 40 Brazilians - joined these units. Although coordinated 
 by the communists, the Brigades had 
 members from socialist, liberal, and other 
 political-ideological currents. 

 SOUZA, I. I. The European Civil War. Living History, n. 70, 2009 (excerpt).
question: What was the main objective of the International Brigades during the Spanish Civil War?
options: {'A': 'Defend the Spanish monarchy.', 'B': 'Fight in defense of the Spanish Republic.', 'C': 'Promote fascism in Spain.', 'D': 'Establish a communist government in Spain.', 'E': 'Protect foreign interests in Spain.'}
correct_answer: {'B': 'Fight in defense of the Spanish Republic.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the International Brigades during the Spanish Civil War. The bloom and difficulty level seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct option is not specified in the question stem.
system_answer: {B: Fight in defense of the Spanish Republic.}
steps_answer: The main objective of the International Brigades during the Spanish Civil War was to fight in defense of the Spanish Republic, as mentioned in the provided text.

context:
Of all the transformations imposed by the technical-scientific-informational environment on transport logistics, we are most interested in intermodality. And for a very simple reason: the potential that such a 'logistic tool' boasts allows for a transportation system that is indeed commensurate with Brazil's geographical scale.
HUERTAS, D. M. The role of transportation in the recent expansion of the Brazilian agricultural frontier. Transport and Territory Journal, University of Buenos Aires, n. 3, 2010 (adapted).
question: What is intermodality in the context of transport logistics?
options: {'A': 'A transportation system that uses only one type of mode, such as trucks.', 'B': 'The integration of different modes of transportation, such as road, rail, and maritime, aiming at optimization and efficiency.', 'C': 'An exclusive transportation system for dangerous goods.', 'D': 'The use of air transport for all logistical operations.', 'E': 'A transportation system that does not concern itself with efficiency and optimization.'}
correct_answer: {'B': 'The integration of different modes of transportation, such as road, rail, and maritime, aiming at optimization and efficiency.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context of transport logistics and intermodality. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question provides clear information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option is accurate and aligns with the definition of intermodality in transport logistics.
system_answer: {B: The integration of different modes of transportation, such as road, rail, and maritime, aiming at optimization and efficiency.}
steps_answer: In the context of transport logistics, intermodality refers to the integration of different modes of transportation, such as road, rail, and maritime, with the aim of optimizing and increasing efficiency in the transportation system. This allows for a more effective and seamless movement of goods across different transportation networks.

context: Hence arises a question: whether it is better to be loved than feared, or feared than loved. It is answered that both would be desirable; but because it is difficult to unite them, it is much safer to be feared than loved, when one of the two must be lacking. For men can generally be said to be ungrateful, fickle, pretenders, cowards and greedy for profit, and while you do them good they are entirely yours, offering you blood, goods, life and children, when, as I said above, the danger is far away; but when it comes, they revolt.
question: According to the passage, why does Machiavelli state that it is safer to be feared than loved?
options: {'A': 'Because men are naturally good and loyal when loved.', 'B': 'Because men are ungrateful, fickle, pretenders, cowards and greedy for profit.', 'C': 'Because being loved implies greater risks than being feared.', 'D': 'Because being feared does not bring political benefits.', 'E': 'Because being loved is easier to achieve than being feared.'}
correct_answer: {'B': 'Because men are ungrateful, fickle, pretenders, cowards and greedy for profit.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided from Machiavelli's text. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty are appropriate for an intermediate understanding. The question provides enough information to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option aligns with Machiavelli's reasoning in the passage.
system_answer: {B: Because men are ungrateful, fickle, pretenders, cowards and greedy for profit.}
steps_answer: In the passage, Machiavelli states that it is safer to be feared than loved because men are generally described as ungrateful, fickle, pretenders, cowards, and greedy for profit, making it difficult to maintain their loyalty when loved.

context: Hence arises a question: whether it is better to be loved than feared, or feared than loved. It might be answered that we should wish to be both; but since love and fear can hardly exist together, if we must choose between them, it is far safer to be feared than loved when one of the two must be lacking. For men in general are ungrateful, voluble, dissemblers, anxious to avoid danger, and covetous of gain; as long as you benefit them, they are entirely yours; they offer you their blood, their goods, their life, and their children, as is said above, when the necessity is far distant; but when it approaches, they revolt.
question: What is the main reason presented by Machiavelli to justify why men revolt when danger is near?
options: {'A': 'Because men are naturally brave and altruistic.', 'B': 'Because men are loyal only when danger is imminent.', 'C': 'Because men are cowardly and selfish, acting in their own benefit.', 'D': 'Because men are unpredictable and inconsistent in their actions.', 'E': 'Because men are more likely to follow beloved leaders than feared ones.'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'Because men are cowardly and selfish, acting in their own benefit.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided from Machiavelli's perspective. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for analyzing the main reason behind men's behavior. The question provides enough information to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option aligns with Machiavelli's argument in the context.
system_answer: {C: Because men are cowardly and selfish, acting in their own benefit.}
steps_answer: Machiavelli justifies that men revolt when danger is near because they are described as ungrateful, voluble, dissemblers, anxious to avoid danger, and covetous of gain, acting in their own benefit.

context: Hence arises a question: whether it is better to be loved than feared, or feared than loved. It might be answered that both would be desirable; but because it is difficult to unite them, it is much safer to be feared than loved, when one of the two must be lacking. For men in general are ungrateful, fickle, simulators and deceivers, avoiders of danger, greedy for gain; while you do them good, they are entirely yours, offering you their blood, property, life, and children, as I said above, when the need is far distant; but when it approaches, they turn against you.
question: What is the main characteristic of men mentioned by Machiavelli that justifies the preference for being feared instead of loved?
options: {'A': 'Loyalty', 'B': 'Generosity', 'C': 'Ingratitude', 'D': 'Altruism', 'E': 'Honesty'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided from Machiavelli's work. The bloom taxonomy level 'Recall' and difficulty level 'Beginner' are appropriate for the question. steps_answer: Machiavelli mentions that men in general are ungrateful, fickle, simulators and deceivers, avoiders of danger, greedy for gain, which justifies the preference for being feared instead of loved.

context:
At the end of the 19th century, the Great Carnival Societies 
reached wide popularity among the carioca revelers. Such societies cultivated a pretentious 
objective regarding the carnival celebration itself: with their parades of decorated cars through 
the main streets of the city, they intended to abolish the 'entrudo' 
(a game consisting of throwing water at revelers) and other practices widespread among the population since colonial times, replacing them with forms of entertainment 
that they considered more civilized, inspired by the carnivals of Venice. However, no one seemed willing 
to give up their amusements to attend the societies' carnival. The 'entrudo', in the view of its lively 
practitioners, could perfectly coexist with the parades.
question: What was the objective of the Great Carnival Societies regarding the carnival celebration at the end of the 19th century?
options: {'A': 'Replace the 'entrudo' with more civilized forms of entertainment.', 'B': 'Maintain the 'entrudo' as the main practice during the carnival.', 'C': 'Inspire themselves in the carnivals of Salvador for their parades.', 'D': 'Completely eliminate the carnival festivities.', 'E': 'Hold parades of decorated cars only in enclosed locations.'}
correct_answer: {'A': "Replace the 'entrudo' with more civilized forms of entertainment."}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the Great Carnival Societies at the end of the 19th century. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty are appropriate for a comprehension level and intermediate difficulty. The correctness score is 1 as the correct option is accurately stated as 'Replace the 'entrudo' with more civilized forms of entertainment.' Well-constructed question overall.

context:
So, crossing the backlands paths is more 
exhausting than crossing a bare steppe. In the latter, at least, 
the traveler has the relief of a wide horizon and the perspective of open plains. Whereas the former 
drowns him; shortens his sight; assaults and dazzles him; 
entangles him in the thorny web and does not attract him; repels him 
with stinging leaves, with thorns, with splintered twigs 
stuck like spears, and unfolds before him leagues and 
leagues, unchanging in its desolate aspect; tree without leaves, 
with twisted and dry branches, tangled, 
pointing rigidly in space or stretching flexuously 
along the ground, resembling an immense flailing, of torture, of the 
dying flora...

CUNHA, E. Os sertões. Available at: http://pt.scribd.com. Accessed on: Jun 2, 2012.

context:
In the social production that men carry out, they 
enter into certain relations that are indispensable 
and independent of their will; such production relations 
correspond to a defined stage of development 
of their material forces of production. The totality 
of these relations constitutes the economic structure 
of society - the real foundation on which the political 
and legal superstructures are built, and to which 
certain forms of social consciousness correspond.

MARX, K. Preface to the Critique of Political Economy. In: MARX, K.; ENGELS, F. 
Texts 3. São Paulo: Social Editions, 1977 (adapted).
question: According to the text, what is the real foundation on which the political and legal superstructures are built?
options: {'A': 'Production relations', 'B': 'Material forces of production', 'C': 'Economic structure of society', 'D': 'Social consciousness', 'E': 'Real foundation'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about humanities and their technologies. The Bloom's level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'A: Production relations' aligns with the information presented in the text.
steps_answer: The text mentions that the totality of production relations constitutes the economic structure of society, which is the real foundation on which the political and legal superstructures are built.

context:

context: To prevent abuse, it is necessary to organize things in such a way that power is contained by power. Everything would be lost if the same man or the same body of the rulers, or the nobles, or the people, exercised these three powers: the power to make laws, the power to execute public resolutions and the power to judge crimes or individual disagreements. Thus, the Legislative, Executive and Judiciary powers are created, acting independently for the realization of freedom, which does not exist if the same person or group exercises the mentioned powers simultaneously. MONTESQUIEU, B. The Spirit of the Laws. São Paulo: Abril Cultural, 1979 (adapted).
question: According to Montesquieu, what is the reason for the separation of the Legislative, Executive and Judiciary powers?
options: {'A': 'To centralize power in a single person.', 'B': 'To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.', 'C': 'To increase the concentration of power in the hands of the people.', 'D': 'To make the governance of the State more difficult.', 'E': 'To allow direct interference of the people in political decisions.'}
correct_answer: {'B': 'To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about Montesquieu's separation of powers theory. It aligns with the Understand level of Bloom's Taxonomy and is suitable for beginners. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct answer is not specified in the question stem.
system_answer: {B: To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.}
steps_answer: Montesquieu believed that the separation of Legislative, Executive, and Judiciary powers was necessary to prevent abuses of power and ensure freedom. This separation would prevent one person or group from having control over all three powers, which could lead to tyranny and oppression.

question: Why does Montesquieu advocate for the independent action of the Legislative, Executive and Judiciary powers?
options: {'A': 'To facilitate the concentration of power.', 'B': 'To allow direct interference of the people in political decisions.', 'C': 'To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.', 'D': 'To increase the centralization of power in a single person.', 'E': 'To hinder the governability of the State.'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.'}

system_answer: {C: To ensure the realization of freedom and prevent abuses of power.}
steps_answer: Montesquieu advocates for the independent action of the Legislative, Executive, and Judiciary powers to prevent abuses of power and ensure freedom. He argues that if one person or group holds all three powers (making laws, executing public resolutions, and judging crimes), it could lead to tyranny and the loss of freedom. By separating these powers, each branch can act independently, providing a system of checks and balances to prevent any one branch from becoming too powerful.

context:
When no one doubts the existence of another world, death is a passage that should be celebrated among relatives and neighbors. The man of the Middle Ages is convinced of not disappearing completely, hoping for the resurrection. For nothing stops and everything continues in eternity. The contemporary loss of religious feeling has made death a terrifying ordeal, a springboard to darkness and the unknown.

DUBY, G. Year 1000 year 2000 on the trail of our fears. São Paulo: Unesp, 1998 (adapted).

context:
The building is circular. The prisoners' apartments 
occupy the circumference. You can call them, if you 
want, cells. The inspector's apartment occupies the 
center; you can call it, if you want, the inspector's lodging. Reformed morality; preserved health; revitalized industry; widespread education; public burdens relieved; settled economy, as it should be, on a rock; the Gordian knot of the Law on the Poor not cut, but undone - all by a simple architectural idea!

BENTHAM, J. The Panopticon. Belo Horizonte: Autêntica, 2008.

context:
During the royalty, and in the early republican years, 
the laws were transmitted orally from one generation to 
another. The absence of a written legislation allowed the 
patricians to manipulate justice according to their interests. 
In 451 B.C., however, the plebeians managed to elect 
a commission of ten people — the decemvirs — to 
write the laws. Two of them traveled to Athens, in Greece, 
to study Solon's legislation.

COULANGES, F. The ancient city. São Paulo: Martins Fontes, 2000.
question: What year did the plebeians manage to elect the decemvirs to write the laws?
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the transmission of laws in ancient Rome. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. context:
The happiness is, therefore, the best, the noblest and the most pleasant thing in the world, and these attributes should not be separated as in the existing inscription in Delphi 'of things, the noblest is the most just, and the best is health; but the sweetest is to have what we call'. All these attributes are present in the most excellent activities, and among these the best, we identify as happiness.

ARISTOTLE. Politics. São Paulo: Cia. das Letras, 2010.

options: {'A': 'Happiness is the most just and sweetest thing in the world.', 'B': 'Happiness is the noblest, the most just and the sweetest thing in the world.', 'C': 'Happiness is the most pleasant and sweetest thing in the world.', 'D': 'Happiness is the noblest and most pleasant thing in the world.', 'E': 'Happiness is the most just and most pleasant thing in the world.'}

context:
TEXT I

Our fight is for the democratization of land ownership, increasingly concentrated in our country. About 1% of all landowners control 46% of the land. We exert pressure through the occupation of unproductive large estates and properties that do not fulfill their social function, as determined by the 1988 Constitution. We also occupy farms that have their origins in the illegal occupation of public lands.

Available at: www.mst.org.br. Accessed on: Aug 25, 2011 (adapted).

TEXT II

The small rural landowner is similar to a small shop owner: the smaller the business, the harder it is to maintain, as it must be productive and the burdens are difficult to bear. I am in favor of productive and sustainable properties that generate jobs. Supporting a productive company that creates jobs is much cheaper and generates much more than supporting agrarian reform.
LESSA, C. Available at: www.observadorpolitico.org.br. Accessed on: Aug 25, 2011 (adapted).
question: According to Text I, what is the main objective of the mentioned fight?
options: {'A': 'Increase the concentration of land in the hands of a few.', 'B': 'Promote the occupation of small rural properties.', 'C': 'Democratize land ownership.', 'D': 'Encourage the illegal occupation of public lands.', 'E': 'Disregard the 1988 Constitution.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about land ownership and occupation in Brazil. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'C: Democratize land ownership' aligns with the main objective mentioned in Text I.
steps_answer: 1. In Text I, it is mentioned that the fight is for the democratization of land ownership. 2. The text highlights the concentration of land in the hands of a few and the need to exert pressure through occupation to fulfill the social function of properties.

context:
Having faced the beast of the past eye to eye, 
having asked for and received forgiveness and having made corrections, 
let us now turn the page — not to forget it, 
but not to let it forever imprison us. 
Let us move towards a glorious future of a new South African society, where people are valued 
not because of biological irrelevancies or other 
strange attributes, but because they are people of infinite value created in the image of God. 
Desmond Tutu, at the closing of the Truth Commission in South Africa. Available at: 
http://td.camara.leg.br. Accessed on: Dec 17, 2012 (adapted).

context:
No one is unaware of the need that all 
farmers have to increase the number of their 
workers. And how did farmers supply the necessary 
arms until recently? Farms were fueled by the acquisition of slaves, without the slightest 
financial aid from the government. Now, if farmers supplied arms at their own expense, and if it is still possible to obtain them, albeit of a different quality, why should they not seek to achieve them in the same way, that is, at their own expense? 

Response from Manuel Felizardo de Sousa e Mello, general director of Public Lands, 
to Senator Vergueiro. In: ALENCASTRO, L. F. (Org.). History of private life in Brazil. 
São Paulo: Cia. das Letras, 1998 (adapted).
question: What was the common practice of farmers to meet the need for workers on farms?
options: {'A': 'Hiring temporary workers', 'B': 'Acquisition of slaves', 'C': 'Partnerships with the government', 'D': 'Programs to encourage voluntary work', 'E': 'Importation of foreign labor'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided, testing understanding of historical practices related to farm labor. The bloom taxonomy level 'Recall' is appropriate as it requires remembering a specific fact. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'B: Acquisition of slaves' aligns with the historical context presented.
steps_answer: The passage mentions that until recently, farmers supplied the necessary workers by acquiring slaves without financial aid from the government.

context:
Until today it was assumed that our knowledge was 
regulated by objects; however, all attempts to 
discover, through concepts, something that would expand our 
knowledge, failed with this assumption. 
Let us try, then, once, to see if the tasks of metaphysics will not be better solved by assuming that 
objects should be regulated by our knowledge. 
KANT, I. Critique of Pure Reason. Lisbon: Calouste-Gulbenkian, 1994 (adapted).
question: According to the text, what is Kant's proposal for solving the tasks of metaphysics?
options: {'A': 'Regulate objects by knowledge.', 'B': 'Regulate knowledge by objects.', 'C': 'Expand knowledge through objects.', 'D': 'Ignore the relationship between objects and knowledge.', 'E': 'Eliminate metaphysics as a discipline.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided and tests comprehension of Kant's proposal as mentioned in the text. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty level are appropriate for the given information. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'A: Regulate objects by knowledge.' aligns with Kant's proposal as stated in the text.
steps_answer: The text mentions that Kant's proposal for solving the tasks of metaphysics is to regulate knowledge by objects, as opposed to the traditional assumption of regulating knowledge by objects.

context:
Until today it was assumed that our knowledge was 
to be regulated by objects; however, all attempts to 
discover, through concepts, something that would expand our

objects should be regulated by our knowledge. 
KANT, I. Critique of Pure Reason. Lisbon: Calouste-Gulbenkian, 1994 (adapted).

options: {'A': 'Objects should be ignored in the search for knowledge.', 'B': 'Knowledge should be limited by sensory experience.', 'C': 'Objects should be subordinated to knowledge.', 'D': 'Knowledge should be built from objects.', 'E': 'Knowledge should regulate objects.'}

steps_answer: Kant proposed that the tasks of metaphysics would be better solved by assuming that objects should be regulated by our knowledge, indicating that knowledge should regulate objects.

context:
The recovery of African cultural heritage must take into account what is proper to the cultural process: its movement, plurality, and complexity. It is not, therefore, about the naive rescue of the past or its nostalgic cultivation, but about seeking to perceive the Brazilian cultural face. What is wanted is to capture its movement to better understand it historically.

MINAS GERAIS. Cadernos do Arquivo 1: Escravidão em Minas Gerais.
Belo Horizonte: Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1988.

context:
TEXT I

She wakes up late after going to the theater and dance; 
she reads novels, besides wasting time looking 
out the window or balcony; spends hours 
at the dressing table fixing her complicated hairstyle; an 
equal number of hours practicing piano and more in 
her French or dance class. 
Comment by Father Lopes da Gama about female customs [1839] apud SILVA, T. 
V. Z. Women, culture and Brazilian literature. Ipotesi — Journal of Literary Studies, 
Juiz de Fora, v. 2. n. 2, 1998. 

TEXT II

The windows and doors barred with trellises were not 
confessed, positive chains; but they were, by appearance and 
by their purpose, large cages, where parents and husbands 
watched over, hidden from society, their daughters and wives.

Accessed on: May 20, 2013 (adapted).

context:
The products and their consumption constitute the declared goal of technological enterprise. This goal was first proposed at the beginning of Modernity, as an expectation that man could dominate nature. However, this expectation, converted into a program announced by thinkers such as Descartes and Bacon and driven by the Enlightenment, did not arise 'from a pleasure of power', 'from a mere human imperialism', but from the aspiration to liberate man and enrich his life, physically and culturally.

CUPANI, A. Technology as a philosophical problem: three approaches. Scientiae Studia, São Paulo, v. 2, n. 4, 2004 (adapted).
question: What was the declared goal of the technological enterprise proposed at the beginning of Modernity?
options: {'A': 'Dominate nature', 'B': 'Enrich nature', 'C': 'Destroy nature', 'D': 'Ignore nature', 'E': 'Adapt to nature'}

The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct answer 'A: Dominate nature' aligns with the information presented in the text.
steps_answer: The text mentions that the declared goal of the technological enterprise proposed at the beginning of Modernity was the expectation that man could dominate nature.

context:
The slavery shall not be suppressed in Brazil by a servile war, much less by insurrections or local attacks. Nor should it be, by a civil war, as it was in the United States. It could disappear, perhaps, after a revolution, as it happened in France, this revolution being the exclusive work of the free population. It is in Parliament and not on farms or quilombos in the interior, nor in the streets and squares of the cities, that the cause of freedom must be won or lost.

NABUCO, J. Abolitionism [1883]. Rio de Janeiro: Nova Fronteira; São Paulo: Publifolha, 2000 (adapted).

context:
I am 44 years old and witnessed an impressive transformation in the condition of gay men and women in the United States. When I was born, homosexual relationships were illegal in all the United States, except Illinois. Gays and lesbians could not work in the federal government. There was no openly gay politician. Some closeted homosexuals held positions of power, but the trend was for them to make things even worse for their peers.

ROSS, A. In the time machine. Época, ed. 766, 28 Jan. 2013.

context:
Glucose labeled with carbon-11 nuclides 
is used in medicine to obtain 
three-dimensional images 
of the brain, through positron emission tomography. 
The disintegration of carbon-11 
generates a positron, with a half-life of 20.4 min, 
according to the nuclear reaction equation:

context: Terrestrial plants that are still in the growth phase fix large amounts of CO2, using it to form new organic molecules, and release large amounts of O2. However, in mature forests, whose trees have already reached equilibrium, the consumption of O2 by respiration tends to equal its production by photosynthesis. The natural death of trees in these forests temporarily affects the concentration of O2 and CO2 near the soil surface where they fell.

context:
Females of some species of spiders, scorpions, and other invertebrates prey on males after copulation and insemination. For example, cannibal females of the insect known as praying mantis, Tenodera aridofolia, have up to 63% of their diet composed of male partners. For females, sexual cannibalism can ensure the acquisition of important nutrients in reproduction. With this increase in the diet, they generally produce a greater quantity of eggs.

BORGES, J. Deadly game. Available at: http://cienciahoje.uol.com.br. Accessed on: Mar 1, 2012 (adapted).

context:
In Brazil, about 80% of the electric energy comes from hydroelectric power plants, whose construction involves damming rivers. The formation of a reservoir for this purpose, in turn, can modify the local ichthyofauna. An example is the damming of the Paraná River, where the disappearance of armored catfish was observed almost simultaneously with the increase in the number of introduced exotic species, such as the blackfin pacu and the corvina, the three species with similar ecological niches.

PETESSE, M. L.; PETRERE JR., M. Ciência Hoje, São Paulo, n. 293, v. 49, jun. 2012 (adapted).
question: What is the main environmental impact caused by the construction of hydroelectric power plants?
options: {'A': 'Increase in biodiversity', 'B': 'Disappearance of native species', 'C': 'Decrease in pollution', 'D': 'Creation of new habitats', 'E': 'Reduction of the greenhouse effect'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the environmental impact of hydroelectric power plants. The bloom taxonomy level 'Understand' and difficulty level 'Beginner' are appropriate for the question. The question provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer, which is 'B: Disappearance of native species'. The correctness score is 1 as the correct option is indeed correct.
steps_answer: The main environmental impact caused by the construction of hydroelectric power plants is the disappearance of native species, as mentioned in the passage where the armored catfish disappeared almost simultaneously with the increase in introduced exotic species.

context:
It is known that the increase in the concentration of gases such as 
CO2, CH4, and N2O in the atmosphere is one of the factors responsible 
for the worsening of the greenhouse effect. Agriculture is one of the 
human activities that can contribute to both the emission 
and the sequestration of these gases, depending on 
the management of soil organic matter.

ROSA, A. H.; COELHO, J. C. R. Cadernos Temáticos de Química Nova na Escola,
São Paulo, n. 5, Nov. 2003 (adapted).
question: What can influence whether agriculture will contribute to the emission or sequestration of gases in the atmosphere?
options: {'A': 'Type of cultivation', 'B': 'Management of soil organic matter', 'C': 'Geographical location of the farm', 'D': 'Use of agricultural machinery', 'E': 'Amount of seeds planted'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the greenhouse effect and agriculture's role in gas emission/sequestration. The bloom level and difficulty level are appropriate for the given information. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option is indeed the 'Management of soil organic matter'.
steps_answer: To determine whether agriculture will contribute to the emission or sequestration of gases in the atmosphere, one should consider the management of soil organic matter. This factor plays a crucial role in influencing the outcome.

context:
The frequent formation of large volumes of pyrite 
(<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mtext>FeS</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>) in a variety of mineral deposits favors 
the formation of ferruginous acidic solutions, known 
as "acid mine drainage". This phenomenon has 
been extensively researched by scientists and represents 
a major concern among the impacts of mining 
on the environment. In contact with oxygen, at 25 °C, pyrite 
undergoes a reaction, according to the chemical equation:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><msub><mtext>FeS</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>(s)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>(g)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O(l)</mtext><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mtext>Fe</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mfenced><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></sub></mfenced><mn>3</mn></msub><mtext>(aq)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>SO</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(aq)</mtext></math>

feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the formation of pyrite and its reaction with oxygen. steps_answer: The product of the reaction of pyrite (FeS2) with oxygen at 25 °C is Fe2(SO4)3, as indicated in the chemical equation provided.

context: The warfarin is a drug that decreases platelet aggregation, and therefore is used as an anticoagulant, provided that it is present in the plasma, with a concentration greater than 1.0 mg/L. However, plasma concentrations above 4.0 mg/L can trigger hemorrhages. The molecules of this drug are retained in the intravascular space and dissolved exclusively in the plasma, which represents approximately 60% of the blood volume. In a medication, warfarin is administered intravenously in the form of an aqueous solution, with a concentration of 3.0 mg/mL. An adult individual, with a total blood volume of 5.0 L, will undergo treatment with an injectable solution of this medication.

The correctness score is 1 as the correct answer is indeed '1.0 mg/L'. Overall, a well-constructed multiple-choice question.
steps_answer: The minimum plasma concentration of warfarin needed for it to act as an anticoagulant is 1.0 mg/L, as mentioned in the information provided.

context:
I could also decompose water, if it were salty or acidulated, using the Daniell cell as a power source. I remember the extraordinary pleasure I felt when decomposing a little water in a bowl for soft-boiled eggs, watching it separate into its elements, the oxygen on one electrode, the hydrogen on the other. The electricity from a 1-volt cell seemed so weak, and yet it could be enough to break down a chemical compound, water...

SACKS, O. Uncle Tungsten: Memories of a Chemical Childhood. São Paulo: Cia. das Letras, 2002.
question: What is the process described in the text in which water is decomposed into oxygen and hydrogen using the Daniell cell?
options: {'A': 'Photosynthesis', 'B': 'Electrolysis', 'C': 'Decantation', 'D': 'Distillation', 'E': 'Sublimation'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about decomposing water using the Daniell cell. It aligns well with the information given in the passage. The bloom taxonomy level 'Understanding' is appropriate as it requires comprehension of the process described. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct answer should be 'B: Electrolysis' based on the context provided.
steps_answer: The process described in the text in which water is decomposed into oxygen and hydrogen using the Daniell cell is known as electrolysis, where an electric current passes through a liquid or solution causing a chemical reaction that breaks down the compound into its elements.

context:
The production of steel involves heating iron ore, along with coal (carbon) and atmospheric air in a series of redox reactions. The product is called pig iron and contains about 3.3% carbon. One way to eliminate excess carbon 
is through oxidation from heating pig iron with pure oxygen gas. The two main products formed are mild steel (an iron alloy with a remaining carbon content of 0.3%) and carbon dioxide. The approximate molar masses of the elements carbon and oxygen are, 
respectively, 12 g/mol and 16 g/mol.
LEE, J. D. Inorganic Chemistry not so concise. São Paulo: Edgard Blucher, 1999 (adapted).
question: What is the resulting product of heating iron ore, coal, and atmospheric air in a series of redox reactions?
options: {'A': 'Pig iron', 'B': 'Mild steel', 'C': 'Carbon dioxide', 'D': 'Pure oxygen', 'E': 'Iron ore'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the production of steel and the redox reactions involved. The bloom taxonomy level 'Recall' seems appropriate as it requires remembering factual information. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct answer 'Pig iron' is not the resulting product of heating iron ore, coal, and atmospheric air in a series of redox reactions.
steps_answer: The resulting product of heating iron ore, coal, and atmospheric air in a series of redox reactions is pig iron, which contains about 3.3% carbon.

context:
The contamination by the rubella virus is especially concerning in pregnant women, due to congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which can lead to the risk of miscarriage and congenital malformations. Due to specific vaccination campaigns, in recent decades there has been a significant decrease in cases of rubella among women, and, starting in 2008, campaigns have intensified and have given greater focus to the vaccination of young men.

context:
Despite being beautiful and impressive, exotic corals found on Ilha Grande can be a threat to the balance of Rio de Janeiro's coastal ecosystems. Originating from the Pacific Ocean, these organisms were brought by oil platforms and other vessels, probably in the 1980s, and compete with native species for essential elements for survival, such as space and food. Invasive organisms are the second leading cause of biodiversity loss, surpassed only by direct habitat destruction by human action. Invasive species populations grow indefinitely and occupy the space of native organisms.

LEVY, I. Available at: http://cienciahoje.uol.com.br. Accessed on: Dec 5, 2011 (adapted).

context:
Teenagers: taller, fatter, and lazier
The offer of industrialized products and the lack of time have their share of responsibility for the increase in the silhouette of young people. 'Our eating habits, in general, have changed a lot,' observes Vivian Ellinger, president of the Brazilian Society of Endocrinology and Metabolism (SBEM), in Rio de Janeiro. Research shows that here in Brazil, we are overdoing salt and sugar, as well as consuming little milk and eating fewer fruits and beans.

Another sin, a well-known one for those who display excess fat due to gluttony, emerges as a mark of the new generation: laziness. 'One hundred percent of the girls participating in the Program did not practice any sports,' reveals psychologist Cristina Freire, who monitors the emotional development of the volunteers.

You probably already know what the consequences are of a sedentary routine full of fat. 'And it's no news that obese people have a shorter lifespan,' believes Claudia Cozer, endocrinologist of the Brazilian Association for the Study of Obesity and Metabolic Syndrome. But, if five years ago studies projected a bleak future for young people, in the current scenario, the diseases that would come in old age are already part of their routine. 'Teenagers are already suffering from hypertension and diabetes,' Claudia exemplifies.

DESGUALDO, P. Health Magazine. Available at: http://saude.abril.com.br. Accessed on: Jul 28, 2012 (adapted).
question: According to the text, what is one of the factors responsible for the increase in the silhouette of young people?
options: {'A': 'Regular practice of sports.', 'B': 'Excessive consumption of salt and sugar.', 'C': 'Adequate intake of fruits and beans.', 'D': 'Increased consumption of milk.', 'E': 'Reduced consumption of industrialized products.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the increase in the silhouette of young people due to changes in eating habits and lifestyle. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question provides enough information for the reader to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct option is not provided in the question stem.
system_answer: {B: Excessive consumption of salt and sugar.}
steps_answer: The text mentions that in Brazil, people are overdoing salt and sugar, which is one of the factors responsible for the increase in the silhouette of young people.

context:
The game is a voluntary activity or occupation, 
performed within certain and determined limits of time 
and space, according to rules freely consented, but 
absolutely mandatory, endowed with an end in itself, 
accompanied by a feeling of tension and joy and 
awareness of being different from 'everyday life'.
HUIZINGA, J. Homo Ludens: A Study of the Play Element in Culture. Boston: Beacon Press, 1955.
question: What is the definition of game according to Huizinga?
options: {'A': 'Mandatory activity', 'B': 'Voluntary activity', 'C': 'Solitary activity', 'D': 'Paid activity', 'E': 'Physical activity'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the definition of a game according to Huizinga. The correctness score is 1 as the correct answer is 'Voluntary activity'.
steps_answer: The definition of game according to Huizinga is a voluntary activity, as it is mentioned in the passage provided.

context:
New technologies

Currently, there is a prevailing discourse in the media about the exaltation of new technologies, especially those related to telecommunications. Common expressions such as 'the future has already arrived', 'technological wonders' and 'total connection with the world' 'fetishize' new products, turning them into objects of desire, of mandatory consumption. For this reason, today we carry in our pockets, bags, and backpacks the so-celebrated 'future'. However, we cannot reduce ourselves to mere victims of a perverse media apparatus, or of a controlling capitalist apparatus. There is perversion, certainly, and control, without a doubt. Nevertheless, we have developed a symbiotic relationship of mutual dependence with the media vehicles, which tightens with each shared image and with each personal dossier transformed into a public object of entertainment.

No longer like those chained in Plato's cave, we are free to imprison ourselves, by spontaneous will, in this sadomasochistic relationship with the media structures, in which we both control and are controlled.
SAMPAIO, A. S. The microphysics of the spectacle. Available at: http://observatoriodaimprensa.com.br.
Accessed on: Mar 1, 2013 (adapted).
question: According to the text, what is the main criticism regarding the exaltation of new technologies in the media?
options: {'A': 'Transformation into objects of desire and mandatory consumption.', 'B': 'Perverse and capitalist media control.', 'C': 'Symbiotic relationship of mutual dependence.', 'D': 'Fetishization of new products.', 'E': 'Total connection with the world.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the exaltation of new technologies in the media. The bloom taxonomy level 'Understand' and the difficulty level 'Easy' are appropriate for the question. Sufficient information is given in the stem and options to arrive at the correct answer. The correct answer 'B: Perverse and capitalist media control.' aligns with the main criticism presented in the text.
system_answer: {A: Transformation into objects of desire and mandatory consumption.}
steps_answer: The main criticism regarding the exaltation of new technologies in the media, as per the text, is that common expressions fetishize new products, turning them into objects of desire and mandatory consumption.

context:
Hello! Black

The grandchildren of your mulattos and your cafuzos
and the fourth and fifth generations of your suffering blood
will try to erase your color!
And the generations of these generations when they erase
your execrable tattoo,
will not erase from their souls, your soul, black!
Father-João, Mother-black, Fulô, Zumbi,
runaway black, captive black, rebel black
Cabinda black, Congo black, Yoruba black,
black who went to the cotton fields of the USA
to the sugarcane fields of Brazil,
to the trunk, to the iron collar, to the yoke
of all the masters of the world;
I understand better now your blues
in this sad hour of the white race, black!
Hello, Black! Hello, Black!
The race that hangs you, hangs itself out of boredom, black!

LIMA, J. Complete works. Rio de Janeiro: Aguilar, 1958 (fragment).
question: What is the main theme addressed in the presented text fragment?
options: {'A': 'Slavery in Brazil and the United States.', 'B': 'Racial miscegenation and its consequences.', 'C': 'Afro-descendant culture and its resistance.', 'D': 'European colonization in Africa.', 'E': 'Racial segregation in the 20th century.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided, focusing on the main theme of the text fragment. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. Sufficient information is given to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option is indeed 'C: Afro-descendant culture and its resistance.'
steps_answer: The main theme of the text fragment is centered around the Afro-descendant culture and its resistance, showcasing the different generations of black individuals and their struggles against oppression and attempts to erase their identity.

context:
Until when?

There's no use looking at the sky 
With a lot of faith and little fight 
Get up, you have a lot of protests to make

context:
Specific to June festivities, the quadrilha originated as an aristocratic dance, originating from French salons, later spread throughout Europe.

In Brazil, it was introduced as a ballroom dance and, in turn, appropriated and adapted by popular taste. For its occurrence, the presence of a 'remarkable' or 'marker' master is important, as they are the ones who determine the various figures that the dancers perform. The following markings are observed consistently: 'Tour', 'En avant', 'Chez des dames', 'Chez des chevaliê', 'Cestinha de flor', 'Balancê', 'Caminho da roça', 'Olha a chuva', 'Garranchê', 'Passeio', 'Coroa de flores', 'Coroa de espinhos', etc.
In Rio de Janeiro, in an urban context, transformations occur: new figures emerge, the French influence disappears, the use of recordings replaces live music, in addition to the competitive aspect, which supports the quadrilha festivals, promoted by tourism agencies.
CASCUDO, L. C. Brazilian Folklore Dictionary. Rio de Janeiro: Melhoramentos, 1976.
question: What is the origin of the quadrilha as a dance?
options: {'A': 'French salons', 'B': 'Spanish salons', 'C': 'Italian salons', 'D': 'English salons', 'E': 'German salons'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the origin of the quadrilha dance. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at an answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct answer is not marked.
steps_answer: The origin of the quadrilha as a dance is from French salons, as mentioned in the text provided.

context:
Playing fair

Arguing is not winning a discussion at any cost. Convincing someone of something is, first and foremost, an alternative to the practice of winning an issue by shouting or physical violence - or non-physical. Non-physical, colon. A politician who blatantly lies can captivate voters. An advertisement that stoops low can embarrass crowds into consuming a harmful product to the environment. There are psychological manipulations not only in religion. And it is common for people to act emotionally, because they are victims of cunning - and neck-hugging - seduction. Although effectiveness at all costs is not arguing, nor is it about admitting only scientific truths - forming an opinion only after seeing the demonstration and evidence, as science does. Arguing is a matter of everyday life, a form of rhetoric, but it is a reasoning that tries to convince without becoming mere manipulative calculation, and it can be rigorous without being scientific.

Portuguese Language, São Paulo, year 5, n. 66, Apr. 2011 (adapted).
question: What is the main difference between arguing and winning a discussion at any cost?
options: {'A': 'Arguing seeks to convince without manipulation, while winning at any cost involves violence.', 'B': 'Arguing involves physical violence, while winning at any cost is based on scientific facts.', 'C': 'Arguing is based on scientific facts, while winning at any cost involves emotional manipulation.', 'D': 'Arguing is a manipulative calculation, while winning at any cost is a scientific reasoning.', 'E': 'Arguing is a scientific reasoning, while winning at any cost is a form of rhetoric.'}
correct_answer: {'A': 'Arguing seeks to convince without manipulation, while winning at any cost involves violence.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided, focusing on the main difference between arguing and winning a discussion at any cost. The question aligns with the 'Understand' level of Bloom's Taxonomy as it requires the test-taker to differentiate between two concepts. Sufficient information is given in the stem and options to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option accurately reflects the main difference between arguing and winning at any cost.
system_answer: {A: Arguing seeks to convince without manipulation, while winning at any cost involves violence.}
steps_answer: The main difference between arguing and winning a discussion at any cost is that arguing focuses on convincing without manipulation, while winning at any cost may involve resorting to violence or physical force. This is highlighted in the passage where it mentions that arguing is an alternative to winning by shouting or physical violence.

context:
The diva 

 Let's go to the theater, Maria José? 
 I wish, 
 I broke down fifteen kilos of flour into a mess, 
 I'm rotten. Another day we'll go. 
 She said somewhat sad, guilty, 
 and a little happy to refuse with pride. 
 THEATER! She said in the mirror. 
 THEATER! Louder, disheveled. 
 THEATER! And the shards flew 
 without any applause. 
 Perfect. 

 PRADO, A. Oracles of May. São Paulo: Siciliano, 1999.

options: {'A': 'A meeting at the theater', 'B': 'A birthday party', 'C': 'A refusal to go to the theater', 'D': 'A theatrical performance', 'E': 'A vacation trip'}

context:
TEXT I

It is evident that vitamin D is important — but how to obtain it? Really, vitamin D can be naturally produced by exposure to sunlight, but it also exists in some common foods. However, as a source of this vitamin, certain foods are better than others. Some have a significant amount of vitamin D naturally, and are foods that you may not want to overdo: butter, cream, egg yolk, and liver.

Available at: http://saude.hsw.uol.com.br. Accessed on: Jul 31, 2012.

TEXT II

We all know that vitamin D (cholecalciferol) is crucial for your health. But is vitamin D really a vitamin? Is it present in the foods that humans normally consume? Although it exists to some extent in fish fat, vitamin D is not in our diets, unless humans artificially enhance a food product, such as vitamin D enriched milk. Nature intended for you to produce it in your skin, not to put it directly in your mouth.

So, is vitamin D really a vitamin?

Available at: www.umaoutravisao.com.br. Accessed on: Jul 31, 2012.
question: According to TEXT I, what is the main natural way of obtaining vitamin D mentioned?
options: {'A': 'Consumption of butter and cream', 'B': 'Exposure to sunlight', 'C': 'Intake of egg yolk and liver', 'D': 'Consumption of enriched milk', 'E': 'Artificial supplementation'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about obtaining vitamin D from different sources. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test taker to arrive at the correct answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct answer should be 'B: Exposure to sunlight' based on the information provided in TEXT I.
steps_answer: In TEXT I, it is mentioned that vitamin D can be naturally produced by exposure to sunlight.

context:
TEXT I

It is evident that vitamin D is important — but how to obtain it? Really, vitamin D can be naturally produced by exposure to sunlight, but it also exists in some common foods. However, as a source of this vitamin, certain foods are better than others. Some have a significant amount of vitamin D naturally, and are foods that you may not want to overdo: butter, cream, egg yolk, and liver.

Available at: http://saude.hsw.uol.com.br. Access on: Jul 31, 2012.

TEXT II

We all know that vitamin D (cholecalciferol) is crucial for your health. But is vitamin D really a vitamin? Is it present in the foods that humans normally consume? Although it exists to some extent in fish fat, vitamin D is not in our diets, unless humans artificially enhance a food product, such as vitamin D enriched milk. Nature planned for you to produce it in your skin, and not to put it directly in your mouth.

So, is vitamin D really a vitamin?

Available at: www.umaoutravisao.com.br. Access on: Jul 31, 2012.

options: {'A': 'Sun exposure is the only way to obtain vitamin D', 'B': 'Sun exposure is more effective than ingesting foods rich in vitamin D', 'C': 'Sun exposure activates the natural production of vitamin D in the skin', 'D': 'Sun exposure is not related to vitamin D', 'E': 'Sun exposure can cause vitamin D deficiency'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'Sun exposure activates the natural production of vitamin D in the skin'}

context:
The bit in the Gutenberg galaxy

In this century, writing shares ground with various means of communication. This question makes us think about the need for the 'interlocking, coexistence, and reciprocal interpretation of the various circuits of knowledge production and dissemination...'

It is necessary to relativize our stance towards modern technologies, especially computing. It is an innovative field, no doubt, but its foundations are in previous informational models, including, in oral tradition and in the natural ability to mentally simulate events in the world and anticipate the consequences of our actions. Printing is the matrix that triggered this entire electronic communication process. I emphasize, therefore, the kinship between the computer and other means of communication, especially writing, a view of computing as a 'development of what printed literary production and, previously, oral tradition already carried within them.'

NEITZEL, L. C. Available at: www.geocities.com. Accessed on: Aug 1, 2012 (adapted).

context:
Blanket that sews tales and stories within 
a family serves as a metaphor for memory in a work 
written by a Portuguese author

What could be worth more than the blanket for 
that family? Famous painters' paintings? Queen's jewels? Palaces? A blanket made of hundreds of 
scraps of old clothes warmed the children's feet 
and the grandmother's memory, who with each square pointed out by 
her grandchildren rescued a story from her memories. 
Fantasy stories like the one about the dress with a pocket 
that housed a cookie-eating gnome; mischievous stories like the shorts 
transformed into rags on the day the boy, who liked to ride 
his bike with his eyes closed, broke his arm; stories 
of longing, like the apron that carried a letter 
for over a month... Many stories formed that 
blanket. The protagonists were family members, an uncle, 
aunt, grandfather, great-grandmother, herself, the former owners 
of the clothes. One day, the grandmother died, and the aunts started 
to dispute the blanket, they all wanted it, more than the 
paintings, jewels, and palaces left by her. Fortunately, the aunts managed to reach an agreement, and the blanket started 
to stay at one of their houses each month. And the scraps, 
as they ran out, were replaced by 
other scraps, and new and old stories were being 
incorporated into the most valuable blanket in the world.

LASEVICIUS, A. Portuguese Language, São Paulo, n. 76, 2012 (adapted).
question: What object serves as a metaphor for memory in the mentioned work?
options: {'A': 'Famous painters' paintings', 'B': 'Queen's jewels', 'C': 'Palaces', 'D': 'A blanket made of scraps of old clothes', 'E': 'Old books'}
correct_answer: {'D': 'A blanket made of scraps of old clothes'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about a work by a Portuguese author where a blanket serves as a metaphor for memory. The question is clear and directly asks about the object serving as a metaphor. The options are well-structured and the correct answer 'A blanket made of scraps of old clothes' is accurate. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty level seem appropriate for the given information.
system_answer: {D: A blanket made of scraps of old clothes}
steps_answer: The passage describes how a blanket made of hundreds of scraps of old clothes serves as a metaphor for memory in the mentioned work. It symbolizes the memories and stories of the family members, making it more valuable than famous painters' paintings, Queen's jewels, or palaces.

context:
The hypertext allows - or, in some cases, even demands - the participation of several authors in its construction, the redefinition of the roles of author and reader, and the revision of traditional models of reading and writing. Due to its enormous potential to establish connections, it facilitates the development of collectively works, the establishment of communication, and the cooperative acquisition of information.

Although there are those who exclusively identify hypertext with electronic texts, produced in a certain type of medium or technology, it should not be limited to that, since it consists of an organizational form that can be conceived for both paper and digital environments. It is clear that the virtual text allows certain aspects to be realized that are practically unfeasible on paper: immediate connection, comparison of text excerpts on the same screen, the 'dive' into the various deepening of a theme, as if the text had layers, dimensions, or planes.
RAMAL, A. C. Education in cyberculture: hypertextuality, reading, writing, and learning. Porto Alegre: Artmed, 2002.
question: What is a characteristic of hypertext that facilitates the development of collective works?
options: {'A': 'Limitation to a single author.', 'B': 'Restriction to communication between authors.', 'C': 'Facilitation of the participation of several authors.', 'D': 'Inhibition of cooperative information acquisition.', 'E': 'Difficulty in redefining the roles of author and reader.'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'Facilitation of the participation of several authors.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about hypertext and its characteristics. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty level seem appropriate for the given information. The question is clear and provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at an answer. However, the correctness score is 0 as the correct option is not specified in the question.

context:
Sick, I think between sneezes about how the word 
flu came to us after a series of contagions between 
languages. The epidemic of flu 
that spread throughout Europe started in Italy in 1743, in addition to the virus itself, two viral words: the Italian influenza and the French 
flu. The first was a term derived from medieval Latin influentia, which meant 'influence of the stars 
on men'. The second was just the nominal form 
of the verb gripper, that is, 'to grab'. It is assumed that it referred to the violent way the virus takes hold of the infected organism.

RODRIGUES, S. About words. Veja, São Paulo, Nov 30, 2011.
question: What is the original meaning of the Italian term 'influenza'?
options: {'A': 'Influence of the stars on men', 'B': 'To grab', 'C': 'Virus', 'D': 'Violent', 'E': 'Epidemic'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about the origin of the word 'influenza'. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty seem appropriate for a beginner level. The question provides enough information for the test-taker to arrive at the correct answer. The correct answer is 'Influence of the stars on men'.

steps_answer: The original meaning of the Italian term 'influenza' is derived from medieval Latin influentia, which meant 'influence of the stars on men'.

context:
Chapter LIV - The pendulum

I left there savoring the kiss. I couldn't sleep; I lay down in bed, it's true, but it was the same as nothing. I heard 
all the hours of the night. Usually, when I lost sleep, the ticking of the pendulum made me very uncomfortable; that 
somber, slow, and dry tick-tock seemed to say with each 
strike that I was going to have one less moment of life. I imagined then an old devil, sitting between two bags, one of life 
and one of death, and counting them like this:

- Another one less...
- Another one less...
- Another one less...
- Another one less...
The most peculiar thing is that, if the clock stopped, I would wind it up, so that it would never stop ticking, and I could count all my lost moments. There are inventions that change or end; the same institutions die; the clock is definitive and 
perpetual. The last man, bidding farewell to the cold and worn-out sun, must have a clock in his pocket, to know the exact 
time of his death.
That night I did not suffer from that sad feeling of 
boredom, but another, and delightful. Fantasies were tumultuous inside me, they came one after another, like devotees jostling to see the angel-singer of processions. I did not hear the lost moments, but the gained minutes.
ASSIS, M. The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas. Rio de Janeiro: Nova Aguilar, 1992 (excerpt).
question: According to the passage, how did the narrator feel about the sound of the pendulum during the night?

correct_answer: {'B': 'The sound of the pendulum bothered him and made him think about the passage of time.'}

context:
Chapter LIV - The pendulum

I left there savoring the kiss. I couldn't sleep; I lay down in bed, that's for sure, but it was the same as nothing. I heard 
all the hours of the night. Usually, when I couldn't sleep, the ticking of the pendulum made me very uncomfortable; that 
somber, slow, and dry tick-tock seemed to say with each 
stroke that I was going to have one less moment of life. I imagined then an old devil, sitting between two bags, one of life 
and one of death, and counting them like this:

- One less...
- One less...
- One less...
- One less...
The most peculiar thing is that, if the clock stopped, I would wind it up, so that it would never stop ticking, and I could count all my lost moments. There are inventions that change or end; the same institutions die; the clock is definitive and 
perpetual. The last man, bidding farewell to the cold and worn-out sun, must have a clock in his pocket, to know the exact 
time of his death.
That night I did not suffer from that sad feeling of 
boredom, but another, and delightful. Fantasies were tumultuous inside me, they came one after another, like devotees who jostle to see the angel-singer of processions. I did not hear the lost moments, but the gained minutes.
question: What is the narrator's feeling about the gained minutes during that night?
options: {'A': 'He felt bored and anguished with the passing of time.', 'B': 'The gained minutes made him reflect on the finitude of life.', 'C': 'The narrator felt happy and excited with the fantasies that arose.', 'D': 'He associated the gained minutes with a feeling of sadness and loss.', 'E': 'The gained minutes made him fear the arrival of death.'}
correct_answer: {'C': 'The narrator felt happy and excited with the fantasies that arose.'}

context:
For Carr, the internet acts in the commerce of distraction

Author of 'The Shallows' analyzes the influence

of technology on the mind

American journalist Nicholas Carr believes that the
internet does not stimulate anyone's intelligence. The author
explains scientific discoveries about the functioning of the
human brain and theorizes about the influence of the internet
on our way of thinking.

For him, the network makes the reasoning of those who navigate
more shallow, besides fragmenting the attention of its users.
Moreover: Carr asserts that there are companies profiting
from the recent fragility of our attention. 'The more
time we spend online and the faster we move from one
information to another, the more money
internet companies make,' he evaluates.

'These companies are in the commerce of distraction and
are experts in keeping us increasingly hungry for
information fragmented into small parts. It is clear
that they have an interest in stimulating us and taking advantage
of our compulsion for technology.'

ROXO, E. Folha de S. Paulo, 18 Feb. 2012 (adapted).
question: According to Nicholas Carr, what is the main effect of the internet on people's way of thinking?
options: {'A': 'Deepening of reasoning.', 'B': 'Fragmentation of attention.', 'C': 'Stimulation of creativity.', 'D': 'Improvement of memory.', 'E': 'Increase in concentration.'}
feedback: The question is highly relevant to the context provided about Nicholas Carr's views on the influence of the internet on people's thinking. The bloom taxonomy level and difficulty level are appropriate for a comprehension question at an intermediate level. Sufficient information is given to arrive at the correct answer, which is 'B: Fragmentation of attention.' The correct answer is indeed in line with Nicholas Carr's perspective as described in the context.
steps_answer: Nicholas Carr believes that the internet makes the reasoning of those who navigate more shallow and fragments the attention of its users. He asserts that companies profit from the fragility of our attention by keeping us hungry for fragmented information, indicating a main effect of the internet on people's way of thinking as the fragmentation of attention.

context:
In fact, what is commonly called Indians 
is a group of more than three hundred peoples who, together, speak 
more than 180 different languages. Each of these peoples 
has different histories, legends, traditions, concepts 
and views on life, freedom, time 
and nature. In common, these communities 
show a deep communion with the environment in which they live, respect for older individuals, concern for future generations, and the sense that 
individual happiness depends on the success of the group. For 
them, success is the result of a collective construction. 
These ideas, shared by indigenous peoples, are 
esential to build any modern notion of 
civilization. The true representatives of backwardness in 
our country are not the Indians, but those who are guided by prejudiced and outdated views of 'progress'.
AZZI, R. The reasons for being Guarani-Kaiowá. Available at: www.outraspalavras.net. 
Accessed on: Dec 7, 2012.

options: {'A': 'Respect for older individuals.', 'B': 'Concern for future generations.', 'C': 'Individualistic competition for success.', 'D': 'Disregard for the environment in which they live.', 'E': 'Outdated view of progress.'}

The bloom taxonomy level 'Recall' and difficulty level 'Beginner' are appropriate for the question. Sufficient information is given in the stem to arrive at the correct answer. The correct option 'A: Respect for older individuals.' aligns with the information provided in the text.
steps_answer: The text mentions that indigenous communities have a common characteristic of showing respect for older individuals, among other values like concern for future generations and communion with the environment.

context:
What is virtual bullying or cyberbullying?

It is the bullying that occurs in electronic media, with defamatory or threatening messages circulating through emails, websites, blogs (virtual diaries), social networks and cell phones. It is almost an extension of what they say and do at school, but with the aggravating factor that the people involved are not face to face.

In this way, anonymity can increase the cruelty of comments and threats and the effects can be as serious or worse. 'The author, as well as the target, has difficulty in getting out of their role and recovering forgotten values or forming new ones,' explains Luciene Tognetta, a doctor in School Psychology and researcher at the Faculty of Education of the State University of Campinas (Unicamp).

Available at: http://revistaescola.abril.com.br. Accessed on: Aug 3, 2012 (adapted).

options: {'A': 'Bullying that occurs only in electronic media.', 'B': 'Bullying that occurs in electronic media, such as emails, social networks and cell phones, with defamatory or threatening messages.', 'C': 'Bullying that occurs only on blogs.', 'D': 'Bullying that occurs only at school.', 'E': 'Bullying that occurs only face to face.'}
correct_answer: {'B': 'Bullying that occurs in electronic media, such as emails, social networks and cell phones, with defamatory or threatening messages.'}
